conclusion: Initial setup with semi-circular conductor frame in magnetic field, rod OC can slide, resistor R connected.
Rod OC rotates with angular velocity ω, need to find power of external force.
Magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane and directed into it.
Rod OC cuts magnetic field lines, inducing an emf.
Linear velocity v at distance r from O is v = ωr.
Induced emf ε in the rod is ε = B × l × v.
Length l is the chord BC, but OC is rotating around O.
Effective length cutting the field changes with time.
Induced emf is based on rate of change of magnetic flux through area bounded by O, B, C.
Area bounded by O, B, C is a sector of circle with angle θ.
Magnetic flux φ through area is φ = B × 1/2 r² θ.
Induced emf ε is time derivative of flux: ε = B × 1/2 r² × dθ/dt.
Given ω = dθ/dt, simplifies to ε = B × 1/2 r² × ω.
Current I through resistor R is I = ε/R.
Power dissipated in resistor R is P = I²R = ε²/R.
Substituting ε, P = B² r⁴ ω² / 4R.
Power dissipated in R should equal power of external force.
External force does work to maintain rotation against back emf.
